div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE I≈øaack Pennington, Lord Major of the mo≈øt Famous City of London.
div.p:
YOur Honor being the chiefe≈øt Trea≈øurer of the Weal-publicke of this City, I among≈øt the ≈øub≈øcriptions and contributions of well affected per≈øons, have in this Booke, like the Widow, offered into your Trea≈øury but only two mites of Service and Duty, and for it doe mo≈øt humbly pray your gracious favour, and your Honours good acceptance. I know it will appeare ≈øtrange unto ≈øome, who if they di≈ølike my indu≈øtry, and di≈øta≈øte my zeale, I e≈øteem them only tanquam pedarios ≈øen≈øores, trampling on the truth of the Cau≈øe, and carrying their eyes in their heeles, and not in their heads, kicking and ≈øpurning at all zealous and well affected Patriots. But tho≈øe malignant humours
are ≈øo farre from me, and my intents, that in publi≈øhing this booke, I have ≈øcattered abroad the fire of my zeale to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe in its owne ≈øhine, and placed my happine≈ø≈øe in your Honours approving my endeavours. I have verily ca≈øt into your Trea≈øury as much as I could, and for my part doe judge it every mans part to depart from all where hee oweth all that is for the good and ≈øafety of the Commonwealth and the City, which to advance your Honour hath, and doth mo≈øt Religiou≈øly and ≈øtoutly endeavour. To this I can only adde my dayly prayers, and will ≈øtill power them forth to the God of all glory and mercy, that his manifold and dayly ble≈øsings may be multiplied upon your Honour, for your great viligilancy and care over this great City in the≈øe imminent times of Danger, while I de≈øire your approbation of this te≈øtimony of my zeale to your Honour, and pre≈øume to ≈øub≈øcribe my≈øelfe, your Honours mo≈øt humble ≈øervant,

THE happy maintaining of truth in His Maje≈øties Dominions, is the great and mo≈øt honourable employment of all Subjects, but e≈øpecially of tho≈øe unto whom the good of the Subject is in a more peculiar manner intru≈øted, that are ≈øo many Patres Patriae, ≈øo many Fathers of their Countrey to di≈øpo≈øe and defend the Rights, Priviledges, and Intere≈øts of their Countrey, and the liberties of the Subject; ≈øuch are the two honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament, and all Magi≈øtrates who ought to comply with His Maje≈øty, ≈øo farre as His Maje≈øty doth comply with truth; and truth is defined to be conformitas rei cum intellectu, the conformity of any thing with the under≈øtanding. Now in matters of Religion, the will of God is the object of the under≈øtanding, ≈øo that if the intellect or under≈øtanding be not rightly informed and conformed to Gods revealed will and word, that Religion is fal≈øe and erronious, and ≈øuch are the Idolatrous opinions of the Papi≈øts, being conformed only to the will of humane traditions and inventions, altogether repugnant to the Doctrine of Chri≈øt, and his Apo≈øtles.

And if the Delinquents who now ≈øwarme in Armes about the King, have by force and evill coun≈øell rai≈øed an unhappy divi≈øion under fair pretences of Religion, which they intend to overthrow, and will maintaine Idolatry to be truth, the violation of all Lawes divine and humane to be truth, ≈øint omnia protinus alba, let all things, even blacke it ≈øelfe be called white. But if the≈øe Delinquents, and Malignants did in the
fir≈øt place ≈øow private ≈øeeds of di≈ø≈øention betweene the King and His Parliament, & in vulgus ≈øpargere ≈øemina, and afterward di≈øper≈øt them among≈øt the vulgar people; if they by pernicious coun≈øell drew fir≈øt His Maje≈øties affection, then His Per≈øon away from the Parliament, then banded them≈øelves into a great Army again≈øt the Parliament, again≈øt the Subject, and mo≈øt e≈øpecially again≈øt the Prote≈øtant Religion, who≈øe ruine they had formerly contrived; and finding that all their intentions were by divine providence blowne away, like the venemous worke of the Spider, in publicum exitio≈øi, nihil ≈øpei, ni≈øi per di≈øcordias habent, tamen, Deus & Rex, & pretio≈øa nomina praet exuntur, they are Tacitus his words with little alteration; the≈øe men de≈øtructive to the Common-wealth, had no hope to bring about their Idolatrous and wicked intents, but by pretending tho≈øe pretious names of God and the King, as ≈øtanding in their defence, when indeed they oppo≈øe both, ≈øeeing none can ≈øtand for God and the King truly and lawfully, unle≈ø≈øe he ≈øtand al≈øo for the good of the Subject, of the maintenance of the Prote≈øtant Religion.

Truth doth not con≈øi≈øt in any duality of good and evill, of right and wrong, of reall and counterfeit, of verball and ≈øub≈øtantiall, but like a dye throwne by the hand of adver≈øity, or powerfull oppo≈øition doth alwaies ≈øet upon a ≈øquare, it is one and the ≈øame ≈øtill like it ≈øelfe, and therefore indeed it is good, becau≈øe it is alwaies one; thus with God who is all goodne≈ø≈øe, there is no ≈øhadow of alteration or changing; but the Divel and his workes are multiplicia, fallacia, and therefore malignantia, ≈øo the malignants of the≈øe times give out that they fight for God, but indeed their meaning is fallacious, for they intend being delinquents to keepe them≈øelves from the cen≈øure of the Law, they would erect againe their ≈øuper≈øtitious Idolatry, and make the land groane againe under monopolies and arbitrary taxations, they would enjoy the liberty of their owne wicked di≈ø≈øolutene≈ø≈øe, and would have no reformation of Religion, le≈øt
they ≈øhould be compelled to a conformation thereunto, and therefore ≈øtand neither for God nor the King, but for their own manifold private ends, and are malignants to God, the King, and the whole State of the Kingdome.

The que≈øtion being thus ≈øtated between the malignants, and tho≈øe who ≈øtand for the maintenance of the true Go≈øpel, and the King, as farre as he ≈øtands for the truth, and is conformable thereunto, it doth appeare how and by whom the Kingdome is now di≈øtracted, the truth ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, we are conformable to God, fir≈øt ≈øeeking his glory, and then the honour of the King, who cannot be the Kin≈øt of malignants and true Prote≈øtants, and therefore we are true obedient ≈øubjects unto his Maje≈øty, in endeavouring to divide tho≈øe evill coun≈øellours from him, and to bring the King and his Subjects to a religious unity con≈øi≈øting of many parts, as the Laws divine and humane, the ju≈øt priviledge of the Subject, by a free and legall government, together with the priviledges of Parliament, all which the≈øe malignants endeavour utterly to ≈øubvert and de≈øtroy.

Et ≈øi hoc in arido, quid in vindi? If this be done (ex facto) by the children of this world unto an evill and malignant end, may not his Maje≈øties great Councell the Parliament (fas e≈øt ab ho≈øte doceri) (ex jure) for the undoubted good of the children of light, and the honour of his Maje≈øty, defend the true Prote≈øtant Religion, the Kings lawfull Power, the ju≈øt liberties of the Subject, and the priviledges of Parliament, and may not Magi≈øtrates (your Honour being the chiefe moderator and governour of this honourable City) comply with the Parliament, in ≈øtanding for the glory of God, the defence of the King, and the maintenance of divine and humane Rights.

It is mo≈øt certaine, that this honourable Citie of London, though much di≈øtracted and di≈øquieted, hath in her greate≈øt feares and jealou≈øies, Anchora fluctuanti Civitati, the Anchor of your Honours wi≈øedome to keep the Citie, though to≈øt on the waves of di≈ø≈øention, fa≈øt to the faith of Chri≈øt, alter & optimus
Tiphis, another and an excellent governour, and chief Ma≈øter of the Cities ≈øhip; ≈øo that as Lelius for wi≈øedome, Metellus for piety, Ari≈øtides for ju≈øtice, were all commended in Roman Hi≈øtories: ≈øo the ancient images of excellent men, were but paternes and re≈øemblances of mans contracted and compleat vertues united in your Honour, being the Atlas of the Citie, bearing the weight and management of all civill affaires on your Honours ≈øhoulders: And therefore, though magnanimity only was attributed to Cyrus, onely mode≈øty to Age≈øilaus, onely wi≈øedome to Themi≈øtocles, skill to Philip, and boldne≈ø≈øe to Bra≈øidus; yet Alexander, as Plutarch reporteth, was furni≈øhed and full fraught with all the≈øe: So your honourable Lord≈øhip is known to be magnanimous, in ≈øtanding for the defence of the true religion, mode≈øt and courteous towards delinquents and offenders, mercifull and compa≈ø≈øionate to the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, wi≈øe and judicious both in politicke and divine matters, and couragiou≈øly bold, maugre all oppo≈øition, to ≈øtand in defence of the true Prote≈øtant Religion, & the policie of the Citie wherof you are the governour, and not only Major, but Optimus; and yet ≈øuch is your Honours magnanimous patience, that you are put or diverted from your re≈øolutions, by the left handed and popular voice, your honour can, as Tacitus ≈øaith, aequo animo laceratam ferre exi≈øtimationem, your Honour can oppo≈øe the malignitie of the times with an invincible patience and magnanimity, knowing that the aim of your de≈øires is the truth and glory of God.

But what doe I ≈øpeake of pa≈ø≈øive vertue? Your actions carry in them the mo≈øt lively portraiture of an able, hone≈øt minde: and though your Honour may thinke, nec ille te novit, qui laudavit, nec tu illum, yet we ≈øhould be all a≈øhamed, qua≈øi canes, latratu accipere quem non agno≈øcimus, to bark at tho≈øe we doe not know; yet what Schollar, nay, what Plebeian can bee ignorant of your great care and vigilancie for the Citie: for though they watch in vain, if God keep not the Citie, yet the eyes of the
Cities have been infallible witne≈ø≈øes of your good propen≈øion and inclination to the ≈øafety of the Citie; ≈øo that wee may ≈øay, Come and ≈øee the legible characters of the honourable Maiors fidelity, love and loyalty to the Citie, in taking order, by direction from the great Councell of the Honourable Parliament, for the building of tho≈øe great, ≈øtrong, and ≈øerviceable fortifications neere and about the Citie of London, Speque, fideque inquit Majora videbis. The Prote≈øtant faith, and the goodne≈ø≈øe of the cau≈øe now undertaken, promi≈øeth greater workes: For,

And here I wi≈øh that I had as many eyes as Argus, to di≈øcover the great co≈øt be≈øtowed upon the≈øe workes; they are rai≈øed to a great height, according to the be≈øt advantages of Geometricall proportions, there is earth heaped upon earth, compacted together according to the dimen≈øions of Art: ≈øo that every Fortification, pondere tuta ≈øuo e≈øt, is ≈øtrong by the weight and worth of the work. My Lord, I will not here ≈øet before you the ab≈øolute Modell of the≈øe fortifications, which are well enough knowne unto your Lord≈øhip, and how many emergent rea≈øons to magnifie and prai≈øe your Lord≈øhip for your fidelious care of the City. My Lord, actions are acknowledged to be the e≈ø≈øence of vertue wherein it con≈øi≈øts, the≈øe workes proceed from the mighty working of Gods Spirit in your heart, from your piety and con≈øtant re≈øolution to defend the Prote≈øtant Religion, and your con≈øtancie in oppo≈øing tho≈øe malignants that would de≈øtroy the King, the Kingdome, and the Parliament, your Honour, nay all the Citie, if they could get acce≈ø≈øe, or make an in rode thereinto.

But your Honour hath in the≈øe dangerous times, when ruine and de≈øtruction doth threaten the Kingdome, and e≈øpecially the Citie, when the true Prote≈øtant Religion is de≈øerted by many, and ≈øcandalized by other Malignants, your Honour doth not re≈øpect the oppo≈øition of Man, though dre≈ø≈øed with
the flouri≈øh and pomp of Maje≈øticall words; and yet herein lies your greate≈øt, that you a≈øcribe all prai≈øe unto God the Lord of Hoa≈øts, which worketh with wonderfull wi≈øedome, and bringeth excellent things to pa≈ø≈øe. Religion is not unlike the ≈øoule in the body of man: for in the whole Common-wealth it is or ≈øhould be wholly and every part thereof, tota in toto & tota in qualibet parte: it hath ≈øhewed your Honour the way for common good, and it ≈øhould direct all the parts of the Common-wealth to bee compliable for the good of the Common-wealth, and not to hang backward when any matter of co≈øt or charge propounded for the defence and fortification of the Citie: for all ≈øuch are Ho≈øtes intra muros, enemies within the walls.

Every Magi≈øtrate, e≈øpecially Maiors of Cities, are to reduce the Citie into one Monarchicall government, to take care of it, pace quam bello, for a wi≈øe man is a rich man, a very King and an Emperour, and ought to take care of the people under his charge, as if the King him≈øelfe were pre≈øent: For Monarchy hath ≈øeverall parts ≈øubordinate thereunto, who≈øe ends are the ≈øame, namely, to di≈øtribute ju≈øtice, both in reward and puni≈øhment, unto the de≈øerving; to ≈øee the Lawes executed, and by them to keep the ≈øubject from wrong or mole≈øtation: But if Lawes are ≈øilent, and a Citie, as this of London, be threatned by a malignant party, as it is now, ≈øo that En & ecce venit Rex cum ≈øiccariis, behold the King and his Cavaliers are comming, is the daily voice and imagination of the people: then the Maior, as your Honour hath mo≈øt piou≈øly done, ought to fortifie the walls of Jeru≈øalem, to look that ≈øtrength may bee provided to oppo≈øe the enemy: And herein your care and vigilancy have declared them≈øelves. Your Honour hath heard how other Cities and great Townes have been plundered by the malignant party, and how earne≈øtly they demon≈øtrate their cruelty upon the famous City of London; but your Honour hath taken advice of the Parliament, a way to oblige po≈øterity unto
your Honour: For though we have indeed none that fighteth for us, but thou, O God, yet the≈øe Bulworkes and Fortifications made round about the Citie, ≈øhall glorifie your Name to po≈øterity, ≈øhall make your honour to bee accounted the Defender of true Religion, and the pre≈øerver of the whole body of this Citie; Men, women and children, ≈øhall and are glad to ≈øee ≈øuch fortifications rai≈øed for the defence of the Citie, and doe ble≈ø≈øe your Honour for your great care of the City.

The Sleepers in Sardos (Ari≈øt. Phy≈ø.) when they awaked, thought they had pa≈ø≈øed no time; but we ≈øhall be more drow≈øie and ≈øotti≈øh then they, if wee now open not our eyes to acknowledge how happy wee are in your Lord≈øhips care and vigilancy over the Citie; and therefore I may ≈øay by a Briti≈øh Palingene≈øia, as Hypolitus was called Virbius, ≈øo your Honour may be ≈øtiled, Londini civitatis Vly≈ø≈øes, Themi≈øtocles, or by any other name famous for loving and providing for the ≈øecuritie and ≈øafety of the City wherein they were governours. The Citie doth acknowledge it ≈øelfe to have been happy in many great Benefactors, ≈øome whereof have erected Schooles, and endowed them for the propagation of good literature: Others have made their bounty flow out of Aquaducts and Conduits. Some have founded Ho≈øpitalls for maimed impotent people, and given them large revenews; but what hath their ends of their actions been? To be accounted famous and munificent, hiding their ≈øins under the roof of an ho≈øpitall; and it may be, the≈øe great and glorious workes were but ≈øplendida peccata, ≈øhining ≈øinnes. But your Lord≈øhip moved onely with a right godly affection to the cau≈øe of Religion, hath provided for the ≈øafety and protection of this honourable Citie of London: The≈øe out-workes ≈øpeak your love to the Cities good and pre≈øervation, to the true e≈ø≈øence of Religion, to the Parliament and the whole Kingdome and E≈øtate, ≈øo that it may be ≈øaid:

div.p: Xenophon calleth Magi≈øtrates the Kings eyes, the Kings cares, ≈øhoulders, feet and hands; not becau≈øe they ≈øhould ≈øee nothing but what the King plea≈øes, and like and approve of that, or that they ≈øhould heare nothing but the evill coun≈øell of malignants, or that they ≈øhould catch and ≈ønatch one from the other, or carry fire in the one hand, and water in the other; or with the one to offer a gift, and with the other a ≈øtab to whom the King plea≈øes, altera manu panem, altera lapidem; but that Magi≈øtrates eyes, eares, ≈øhoulders, feet and hands, ≈øhould be mutuall helpers one to the other, for the common good and publicke ≈øervice of the whole State; and herein your Honour hath ≈øhewed your ≈øelfe an excellent Magi≈øtrate, complying with the Parliament in all matters that concerne the publicke admini≈øtration of the Common-weale; ≈øo that you have lookt upon the pre≈øent ≈øtate of this Citie and Religion, with the cleare eye of ju≈øtice; you have heard of the great pre≈ø≈øures which the countrey hath endured by the cruelty of the Cavaliers; you have to the di≈øcouragement of malignants, on the ≈øhoulders of fortitude, bore and ≈øuffered their fal≈øe a≈øper≈øions, and aequo animo lacer atam ferre exi≈øtimationens, is as Tacitus ≈øaith, the true note and property of a wi≈øe man; and your honour hath in your pre≈øent Magi≈øtracie walked uprightly, having clean and pure hands; nay, ≈øtrong hands: for your Honour hath been the chiefe≈øt rai≈øer and promoter of the workes and fortifications round about the Citie of London; you ≈øaw the times were dangerous, and that the Kings Cavaliers g ‚Ä¢ ped after nothing more then to get London, and make it a prey to the ≈øupplying of their nece≈ø≈øities. This made the Parliament and your Lord≈øhip to take order for the fortification of the Citie, to prevent the malice of our enemies, who marching under the name of the King, would de≈øtroy both the Citie and the Kingdome.

Nature witty in policie, hath given to all creatures a naturall in≈øtinct to fortifie and pre≈øerve them≈øelves, ad con≈øervationem ≈øpecierum, the earth hath mountaines to keep off the fierce inva≈øions
